articles.author: Justin Spike, Aamer Madhani
articles.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is meeting with President Donald Trump in Washington. Friday's meeting is a pivotal moment for Zelenskyy's country, one that hinges on whether he can persuade the Republican to provide some form of U.S. backing for Ukraine’s security against any future Russian aggression. During the visit, Ukraine is expected to sign a landmark economic agreement with the U.S. that would bind the two countries economically for years. But Zelenskyy insists on firm security guarantees to safeguard his country. There are concerns that Trump may broker a peace deal favoring Russia. But U.S. officials argue American investments in Ukraine will inherently enhance its security.
articles.title: Zelenskyy will meet Trump and seek assurances against future Russian aggression

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.description: Key Republicans and Democrats have been stalwart supporters of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. But a blowup between the Ukrainian leader and President Donald Trump is threatening to change that. Zelenskyy had traveled to Washington to sign a deal Friday that would give the U.S. access to its mineral riches as Trump attempts to pressure Ukraine into a deal to end the war with Russia. Instead, the fallout from a heated Oval Office exchange between Trump, Zelenskyy and Vice President JD Vance further splintered American political support for Ukraine. Sen. Lindsey Graham, who has backed Ukraine, called the meeting a “complete, utter disaster."
articles.title: What US lawmakers are saying about the White House clash between Trump and Zelenskyy

articles.author: Adriana Gomez Licon
articles.description: President Donald Trump and Vice President JD Vance had a heated exchange with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in the Oval Office over the war in Ukraine, accusing him of not showing gratitude after he challenged Vance on the question of diplomacy with Russia’s Vladimir Putin. The argument, broadcast globally on Friday, was perhaps unique in American history. It led to the rest of Zelenskyy’s White House visit being canceled and called into question how much the U.S. will still support Ukraine in its defense against Russia’s 2022 invasion.
articles.title: A transcript of Trump and Zelenskyy's Oval Office argument

articles.author: Justin Spike
articles.description: Soon after Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy left the White House after an astonishing Oval Office blowout with President Donald Trump, Ukrainians rallied around Zelenskyy as a defender of his country's interests. Trump and Vice President JD Vance berated Zelenskyy during an Oval Office meeting on Friday for what they saw as a lack of gratitude for past U.S. aid, a confrontation that pleased Moscow. The friction cast doubt on future U.S. support for Ukraine amid its war with Russia. But despite the diplomatic fallout, many Ukrainians supported Zelenskyy’s firm stance. Officials across Ukraine praised their leader's resilience, while some cautioned against losing crucial U.S. backing.
articles.title: After Oval Office blowout, Ukrainians rally around Zelenskyy as defender of Ukraine's interests

articles.author: Fernanda Figueroa
articles.description: President Donald Trump is expected to sign an executive order designating English as the official language of the United States, and activists and advocacy groups are alarmed by what that will mean for non-English speakers when it comes to immigration, voter access and other issues. Designating English as the national language “promotes unity, establishes efficiency in government operations, and creates a pathway for civic engagement,” according to the White House. But some think the move is just another way for the president to stoke division and fear. Currently, more than 30 states in the U.S. already have laws declaring English as the official language.
articles.title: What Trump's order making English the official language in the US could mean

articles.author: Sophia Tareen, Melissa Perez Winder
articles.description: A jury has found a 73-year-old Illinois landlord guilty in a hate crime attack that left a Palestinian American boy dead and injured his mother. Joseph Czuba faced murder, attempted murder and hate crime charges in the death of Wadee Alfayoumi and the wounding of his mother, Hanan Shaheen, in October 2023. Authorities allege that Czuba targeted them because of their Islamic faith and as a response to the war between Israel and Hamas. He had pleaded not guilty. The family was renting rooms from Czuba at a suburban Chicago house. Shaheen testified at the trial that he attacked her with a knife before killing her 6-year-old son in another room. Jurors deliberated less than 90 minutes before handing in a verdict.
articles.title: Jury finds Illinois landlord guilty of murder, hate crime in 2023 attack on Palestinian American boy

articles.author: Susan Montoya Bryan, John Seewer
articles.description: Authorities investigating the deaths of Oscar-winner Gene Hackman and his wife are waiting for more details from their autopsies to determine why they died. Santa Fe County Sheriff Adan Mendoza told NBC’s “Today” show on Friday that both were apparently dead for days or perhaps even a couple of weeks. Hackman and his wife, Betsy Arakawa, were found Wednesday at the couple’s home in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Investigators are trying to figure out the last time anyone saw or spoke to them. The sheriff says there were no signs of any foul play and they are waiting on carbon monoxide and toxicology testing results.
articles.title: Oscar-winner Gene Hackman and wife Betsy Arakawa may have been dead for days or weeks, sheriff says

articles.author: Nicole Winfield
articles.description: The Vatican says Pope Francis suffered a bronchial spasm that resulted in him breathing in vomit, requiring non-invasive mechanical ventilation. The Vatican says he responded well, with a good level of gas exchange, and remained conscious and alert at all times. The episode, reported late Friday by the Vatican, resulted in doctors keeping his prognosis from a two-week battle with double pneumonia as guarded.
articles.title: Pope had a bronchial spasm and his prognosis remains guarded, Vatican says

articles.author: Christopher Rugaber, Anne D'innocenzio
articles.description: Ongoing tariff threats from Washington and potentially sweeping government job cuts have darkened consumers’ mood and may be weighing on an otherwise mostly healthy economy. Data released Wednesday showed that consumers slashed their spending by the most since February 2021, even as their incomes rose. On a positive note, inflation cooled, but President Donald Trump’s threats to impose large import taxes on Canada, Mexico, and China -- the United States’ top trading partners -- will likely push prices higher, economists say. Some companies are already planning to raise prices in response.
articles.title: Tariff threats and uncertainty could weigh on consumers, drag down US economy, gov't report suggests

articles.author: Julia Frankel
articles.description: Mourners buried the remains of one of the last hostages released in the first phase of the ceasefire between Hamas militants and Israel. Negotiators are seeking to iron out a second phase of the deal that could end the war in Gaza and see the remaining live hostages returning home. The body of Tsachi Idan was one of four released by Hamas this week in exchange for over 600 Palestinian prisoners, the last planned swap of the ceasefire’s first phase, which began in January. The relatives of hostages still held in Gaza are ramping up pressure on Netanyahu to secure the release of their loved ones. According to Israel, 32 of the 59 hostages still in Gaza are dead.
articles.title: Mourners bury one of the last hostages released from Gaza as talks start for ceasefire future
